Content: Not the same but check out the Lawyers with ADHD bowl as well
F
Any chance your firm lets you use proofreading software?
I do that. But when I‚Äôm on the go and responding to email on phone it happens. And sometimes proofreaders don‚Äôt pick up legalese

PerfectIt has a legal proofreading format if you‚Äôre interested. It‚Äôs really helpful for formatting and little legalese nits. Not so helpful on the go. I also like the read aloud function on word, saved me a lot of times

Just an fyi - it may be an issue if you are recording calls without others knowledge
Depending on the jurisdiction yes

Some firms have policies against recording even if allowed in the state, FYI.

My brother in law is dyslexic and in accounting. He downloaded a font specifically designed for dyslexia and said it made reading electronic docs a little easier.
Yeah, I know someone who got fired for exactly this. I‚Äôd stop recording calls immediately
This might be the case but if you are diagnosed with dyslexia you can also ask that you be allowed to record as a reasonable accommodation
I‚Äôm kind of scared of reporting to my firm (or any firm) that I‚Äôm dyslexic at all‚Ä¶ I imagine that would blackball me.
I‚Äôm kind of scared of reporting to my firm (or any firm) that I‚Äôm dyslexic at all‚Ä¶ I imagine that would blackball me.
There is software ( even in basic Microsoft )that can read your work out loud to you, so you can catch some spelling mistakes and inverted phrases that way.
Second the read aloud. I have ADHD and have major issues with typos and things, and it really helps, though the robotic voice can get annoying after awhile
Second the read aloud. I have ADHD and have major issues with typos and things, and it really helps, though the robotic voice can get annoying after awhile

I don‚Äôt have dyslexia, but as someone who is bad at spelling and misses my own mistakes, I try to have everything important proofread by a paralegal or proofreader.

For emails, try printing?

Also, outlook, word, and at least some time keeping software let you add words to the dictionary. I add all proper nouns the first time they show up. That way the spellcheck only catches actual misspellings.
Thank you, this is very helpful. I thought justifying text was better but maybe I‚Äôm wrong. I‚Äôll try it
Thank you, this is very helpful. I thought justifying text was better but maybe I‚Äôm wrong. I‚Äôll try it
David Boies has dyslexia

Are you in the US? If so, you seem to have informed your employer of your disability. Given this, you can file a complaint with the federal and state government (you would need to look up how to do so for your state). https://www.ada.gov/file-a-complaint/

You can file a complaint for that. If you feel you are threatened, that's harassment or misconduct in a workplace. Be sure to document the details of the threat and any relevant circumstances as evidence for your complaint.
You need to go to the EEOC.
My question would be " are you threatening me with violence? That's what it sounds like and that certainly constitutes a hostile work environment..."
They just put me on a pip because of the market trends

They know the market is down, makes threats to you, and unwarranted discipline? And you have filed charges or waiting until they terminate you? Your choice either way‚Ä¶ but I would see this as a constructive discharge should you quit.

They know the market is down, makes threats to you, and unwarranted discipline? And you have filed charges or waiting until they terminate you? Your choice either way‚Ä¶ but I would see this as a constructive discharge should you quit.
That‚Äôs crazy anyone would say that to a colleague.
Punch her back if she tries it. Equal rights and opportunity 101. üòÇ
Do it. Her comments about violence and using your dyslexia as a crutch are inappropriate and could be considered harassment. No one should have to endure that kind of treatment at work.
I use Dragon for my carpal tunnel and it‚Äôs quite good
I‚Äôve been training my Dragon Legal since 2014, and am so glad I use it. It is a major RAM hog, though, so you need a fast machine

Hmmm, I don‚Äôt ‚Äòsuffer‚Äô from my dyslexia. It has enabled me to become who I am. I use voice software for texts, but generally type everything else. Severe asthma as a chile gave me the patience to learn how to compensate for the dyslexia.
I haven‚Äôt but would be interested in trying it. What software are you using? Would you recommend it?
I‚Äôm just using the standard one on the iPhone and on Mac. It‚Äôs pretty good. In my opinion it also adds its own punctuation.
The punctuation. Made me laugh.
Every single one of my comments here has been written by dictation software. I don‚Äôt know why but I also overuse commas. I‚Äôll have like a four line run-on sentence with 20 different commas.

I also love the read aloud function in word so I can hear any mistakes
Ido! Our district offers dyslexia endorsement. You might want to look into it.

I have no idea where you can get that, but I think that is so admirable. I think dyslexia is an area that is not addressed enough in schools. Our district basically tells the parents that we can‚Äôt help and that they can seek community resources for it.

Employer: Author works at Ohio Elementary School
Content:
I think that's awful!
I hope things change for your students.
My son and I are both dyslexic. I work with kids through title reading that has to be dyslexic, but I'm not certified to say anything. I hate it! I want to help kids understand that everyone's brain is different, and that doesn't mean dumb or stupid.
Certification is the only way to truly help these students and their families.

Your students and district are so lucky to have you!! Being a speech therapist, I don‚Äôt have anything to do with reading really, but I have had students with phonological disorders that end up having dyslexia. I have always wanted to learn more so I can point parents in a good direction for resources.

Employer: Author works at Ohio Elementary School
Content:
Wilson's offers a certificate program that you could probably check into. I know that with certification, teachers, speech pathologists, and psychologists can diagnose and serve with credentials. I just can't find the requirements for the certification to earn the credentials.

Thank you for the work you do with children. Your job truly helps my job. I love our visiting speech person. We often collaborate on children we share. It also helps if the child is put on an IEP. So, I also work with the SpEd people. We are a team!
